qas.question: What color vestments do Roman Catholic and traditional Protestant clergy wear at liturgical celebrations during Ordinary time?
What is green the color of in the Eastern Catholic Church?
What was worshipped for their ability to maintain their color through the winter season?
What did Romans use as decorations for their winter solstice celebration called Saturnalia?
What does green represent in Ireland and Scotland?
When do clergymen wear orange vestments?
What does the Eastern Catholic Church use orange to represent?
Pentecost was originally what holiday celebrated by the Romans?
Green and what color are represented on the flag of Scotland?
What color is used to represent Romans?

context: Roman Catholic and more traditional Protestant clergy wear <a0_0>green<a0_0/> vestments at liturgical celebrations during <b5_0>Ordinary Time<b5_0/>. In the Eastern Catholic Church, green is the color of <a1_0><b6_0>Pentecost<b6_0/><a1_0/>. <b9_0>Green<b9_0/> is one of the Christmas colors as well, possibly dating back to pre-Christian times, when <a2_0>evergreens<a2_0/> were worshiped for their ability to maintain their color through the winter season. Romans used <a3_0>green holly and evergreen<a3_0/> as decorations for their winter solstice celebration called <b7_0>Saturnalia<b7_0/>, which eventually evolved into a Christmas celebration. In Ireland and Scotland especially, green is used to represent <a4_0>Catholics<a4_0/>, while <b8_0>orange<b8_0/> is used to represent Protestantism. This is shown on the national flag of Ireland.
